metadata.case_name: Dr. G. Narulasiddiah v. First Respondent

facts.text: Appellant and first respondent have the same academic qualifications.
Appellant joined the University as a lecturer in 1945.
Appellant was appointed a temporary Reader in Sanskrit under the University Grants Commission Scheme.
Appellant was appointed a permanent Reader in the University under the UGC Scheme in April 1960.
First respondent joined the University as a lecturer in 1938.
First respondent was appointed a Reader under the University Grants Scheme in January 1961.
In December 1965 the appellant was placed as the Head of the Department of Sanskrit.
In 1967 an appointment had to be made as Professor in the University Grants Scheme.
Claims of the appellant, the first respondent and two other persons were considered by the Board of Appointments.
Candidates were interviewed by the Board and on June 9, 1967 the appellant was given the appointment as Professor.
Appointment approved by the Chancellor of the University on June 29, 1967.
First respondent filed a Writ Petition in the High Court challenging the appointment under Art. 226 of the Constitution.
Learned single Judge of High Court dismissed the writ petition.
First respondent filed an appeal heard by Division Bench of High Court.
Division Bench quashed the appointment on ground of non-compliance with Rule 5, judgment on April 15, 1969.
Appellant applied for special leave to Supreme Court on September 9, 1969, with stay petition.
On September 22, 1969, interim stay granted, respondents to show cause.
On November 14, 1969, Supreme Court modified stay, suspended High Court order till disposal.
On August 26, 1970, clarification that Chancellor free to decide notwithstanding pendency.
Re-constituted Board advised appointment of first respondent; Chancellor decided not to during pendency on November 11, 1970.
Supreme Court granted special leave on December 11, 1970, stay continued.
Appellant had 22 years teaching experience in 1967; first respondent 29 years.
Board's written recommendation: took into consideration academic qualifications, research, teaching experience, performance in interview; unanimously appointed appellant.

legal_issues.text: Whether non-compliance with Rule 5 of the Supplementary Rules (failure to give in writing reasons for overlooking senior claimant with longer teaching service) invalidated the appellant's appointment as Professor.
Whether Rule 5 is mandatory such that absence of express reasons vitiates the appointment, or if there was substantial compliance cured by Chancellor's approval.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule 5 was substantially complied with as Board's recommendation considered teaching experience among other factors.
Chancellor's approval under S. 26(4) gives finality and cures irregularity.
Past preferences to appellant under UGC Scheme show merit over first respondent.
Seniority Rules Rule 7 (1969) deems UGC scale senior to University scale, supporting appellant's seniority.
High Court should have remanded to Board to comply with Rule 5 instead of quashing.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Iveagh v. Minister of Housing; Brayhead Ltd. v. Berkshire County Council

respondent_arguments.text: Rule 5 mandatory: Board must give in writing reasons for overlooking senior with longer teaching service; non-compliance invalidates appointment.
Rules have statutory force; Chancellor's approval does not cure disregard of mandatory provision.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 5 requires reasons for overlooking seniors, but Board's recommendation considered teaching experience along with qualifications, research, interview performance; substantial compliance as experience one factor not determining.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule not intended to load dice in favour of longer experience alone; other considerations like quality of teaching, research, impression at interview matter.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant had 22 years experience vs 29; not negligible difference; past preferences to appellant relevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere length of service does not tip scale.

court_reasoning.text: Failure to expressly state reason is irregularity cured by Chancellor's approval under S.26(4); not per se vitiating.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Board eminently fitted to assess merits.

court_reasoning.text: Will not take notice of second Board's action as if first valid, no jurisdiction for second.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Focus on original June 9, 1967 Board action.

court_reasoning.text: Seniority Rules Rule 7 not applicable retrospectively.

holdings.text: Appointment of appellant valid; non-compliance with Rule 5 does not invalidate as substantial compliance and cured by approval.
Rule 5 treats length of teaching experience as important factor but not outweighing others.

precedents_cited.case_name: Iveagh (Earl) v. Minister of Housing etc.
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by appellant's counsel for remanding instead of quashing for procedural irregularity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brayhead Ltd. v. Berkshire County Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by appellant's counsel for remanding instead of quashing for procedural irregularity.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore University Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs authorities, Board of Appointments constitution, appointment rules by Chancellor, finality of Chancellor's approval.

statutes_cited.name: Supplementary Rules under Mysore University Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Require providing candidate info to Board, consideration of seniors, written reasons for overlooking seniors/higher qualified.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition challenging appointment.

statutes_cited.name: Seniority Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: UGC scale teachers senior to University scale; mentioned but not applied.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, High Court order set aside; held appellant's appointment as Professor valid. Parties to bear own costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Appointment upheld; High Court quashing reversed.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs.

key_quotes.text: "The rule was not intended to load the dice in favour of someone merely because of longer experience as a teacher."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation of Rule 5, rejecting strict seniority.

key_quotes.text: "In our view, rule 5 was substantially complied with by the Board and the failure to record expressly the reason for disregarding the greater length of service of the first respondent did not vitiate the appointment per se."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holding on substantial compliance and curability.

key_quotes.text: "At best it was an irregularity which was cured by the approval of the Chancellor."
key_quotes.speaker: court
